infodynamics.measures.continuous

Class TransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo

  • java.lang.Object
    • infodynamics.measures.continuous.TransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ChannelCalculator, ChannelCalculatorCommon, InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous, TransferEntropyCalculator, EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    TransferEntropyCalculatorGaussian, TransferEntropyCalculatorKraskov, TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateViaCondMutualInfo

    public class TransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo
extends java.lang.Object
implements TransferEntropyCalculator
    A Transfer Entropy (TE) calculator (implementing TransferEntropyCalculator) which is affected using a given Conditional Mutual Information (MI) calculator (implementing ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate) to make the calculations.

    Usage is as per the paradigm outlined for TransferEntropyCalculator, except that in the constructor(s) for this class the implementation for a ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate must be supplied.

    This class may be used directly, however users are advised that several child classes are available which already plug-in the various conditional MI estimators to provide TE calculators (taking specific caution associated with each type of estimator):

    • TransferEntropyCalculatorGaussian
    • TransferEntropyCalculatorKraskov

    Embedding parameters may be automatically determined as per the Ragwitz criteria by setting the property PROP_AUTO_EMBED_METHOD to AUTO_EMBED_METHOD_RAGWITZ or AUTO_EMBED_METHOD_RAGWITZ_DEST_ONLY, or as per the max. bias-corrected AIS criteria by setting the property PROP_AUTO_EMBED_METHOD to AUTO_EMBED_METHOD_MAX_CORR_AIS (as per Garland et al. in the reference list) plus additional parameter settings for these.

    TODO Delete TransferEntropyCalculatorCommon once we've switched everything over to use this? Might be useful to leave it after all, and move common functionality from here to there.

    References:

    • T. Schreiber, "Measuring information transfer", Physical Review Letters 85 (2) pp.461-464, 2000.
    • J. T. Lizier, M. Prokopenko and A. Zomaya, "Local information transfer as a spatiotemporal filter for complex systems" Physical Review E 77, 026110, 2008.
    • Ragwitz and Kantz, "Markov models from data by simple nonlinear time series predictors in delay embedding spaces", Physical Review E, vol 65, 056201 (2002).
    • J. Garland, R. G. James, E. Bradley, "Leveraging information storage to select forecast-optimal parameters for delay-coordinate reconstructions", Physical Review E, Vol. 93 (2016), 022221, doi:
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier, email, www

      static java.lang.String AUTO_EMBED_METHOD_MAX_CORR_AIS
      Valid value for the property PROP_AUTO_EMBED_METHOD indicating that the automatic embedding should be done by maximising the bias corrected AIS, for both source and destination time series

      • k_tau

        protected int k_tau
        Embedding delay to use between elements of the destination embeding vector. We're hard-coding a delay of 1 between the history vector and the next observation however.

        Length of past source history to consider (embedding length)

      • PROP_AUTO_EMBED_METHOD

        public static final java.lang.String PROP_AUTO_EMBED_METHOD
        Property name for specifying which (if any) auto-embedding method to use. Valid values include AUTO_EMBED_METHOD_RAGWITZ, AUTO_EMBED_METHOD_RAGWITZ_DEST_ONLY, AUTO_EMBED_METHOD_MAX_CORR_AIS, AUTO_EMBED_METHOD_MAX_CORR_AIS_DEST_ONLY, AUTO_EMBED_METHOD_MAX_CORR_AIS_AND_TE and AUTO_EMBED_METHOD_NONE. Defaults to AUTO_EMBED_METHOD_NONE

        public void initialise(int k,
              int k_tau,
              int l,
              int l_tau,
              int delay)
                throws java.lang.Exception
        Initialise the calculator for re-use with new observations. New embedding parameters and source-destination delay may be supplied here; all other parameters remain unchanged.
        Parameters:
        k - embedding length of destination past history to consider
        k_tau - embedding delay for the destination variable
        l - embedding length of source past history to consider
        l_tau - embedding delay for the source variable
        delay - time lag between last element of source and destination next value
        Throws:

      • computeStartTimeForFirstDestEmbedding

        protected static int computeStartTimeForFirstDestEmbedding(int k_in_use,
                                        int k_tau_in_use,
                                        int l_in_use,
                                        int l_tau_in_use,
                                        int delay_in_use)
        Protected internal method to set the point at which we can start taking observations from in any addObservations call. User supplied parameters for k etc, so this can be used not only to set the definitive startTimeForFirstDestEmbedding but also when we're searching the parameter space in auto-embedding.

      • setProperty

        public void setProperty(java.lang.String propertyName,
               java.lang.String propertyValue)
                 throws java.lang.Exception
        Sets properties for the TE calculator. New property values are not guaranteed to take effect until the next call to an initialise method.

        Valid property names, and what their values should represent, include:

        • PROP_AUTO_EMBED_METHOD -- method by which the calculator automatically determines the embedding history length (TransferEntropyCalculator.K_PROP_NAME) and embedding delay (#TAU_PROP_NAME) for destination and potentially source. Default is AUTO_EMBED_METHOD_NONE meaning values are set manually; other accepted values include: AUTO_EMBED_METHOD_RAGWITZ for use of the Ragwitz criteria for both source and destination (searching up to PROP_K_SEARCH_MAX and PROP_TAU_SEARCH_MAX), and AUTO_EMBED_METHOD_RAGWITZ_DEST_ONLY for use of the Ragwitz criteria for the destination only; AUTO_EMBED_METHOD_MAX_CORR_AIS for use of the max bias corrected AIS criteria for both source and destination (searching up to PROP_K_SEARCH_MAX and PROP_TAU_SEARCH_MAX), AUTO_EMBED_METHOD_MAX_CORR_AIS_DEST_ONLY for use of this criteria for the destination only and AUTO_EMBED_METHOD_MAX_CORR_AIS_AND_TE for use of this criteria for the target, plus the max bias corrected TE for source embeddings. Use of any value other than AUTO_EMBED_METHOD_NONE will lead to previous settings for embedding lengths and delays (via e.g. #initialise(int, int) or auto-embedding during previous calculations) for the destination and perhaps source to be overwritten after observations are supplied.
        • PROP_K_SEARCH_MAX -- maximum embedded history length to search up to if automatically determining the embedding parameters (as set by PROP_AUTO_EMBED_METHOD) for the time-series to be embedded; default is 1
        • PROP_TAU_SEARCH_MAX -- maximum embedded history length to search up to if automatically determining the embedding parameters (as set by PROP_AUTO_EMBED_METHOD) for the time-series to be embedded; default is 1
        • PROP_RAGWITZ_NUM_NNS -- number of nearest neighbours to use in the auto-embedding if the property PROP_AUTO_EMBED_METHOD has been set to AUTO_EMBED_METHOD_RAGWITZ or AUTO_EMBED_METHOD_RAGWITZ_DEST_ONLY. Defaults to the property value set for ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov.PROP_K
        • Any properties accepted by TransferEntropyCalculator.setProperty(String, String)
        • Or properties accepted by the underlying InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous.setProperty(String, String) implementation.

        Note: further properties may be defined by child classes.

        Unknown property values are ignored.

        Specified by:
        setProperty in interface InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous
        Specified by:
        setProperty in interface TransferEntropyCalculator
        Parameters:
        propertyName - name of the property
        propertyValue - value of the property.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if there is a problem with the supplied value.

      • getProperty

        public java.lang.String getProperty(java.lang.String propertyName)
                             throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous
        Get current property values for the calculator.

        Valid property names, and what their values should represent, are the same as those for InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous.setProperty(String, String)

        Unknown property values are responded to with a null return value.

        Specified by:
        getProperty in interface InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous
        Parameters:
        propertyName - name of the property
        Returns:
        current value of the property
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for invalid property values

      • setObservations

        public void setObservations(double[] source,
                   double[] destination)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculator
        Sets a single series from which to compute the PDF for the channel measure. Cannot be called in conjunction with other methods for setting/adding observations.

        The supplied series are certainly time-series for time-series measures such as transfer entropy, however may be simply a set of separate observations for the mutual information without a time interpretation.

        Specified by:

        Parameters:
        source - series of observations for the source variable.
        destination - series of observations for the destination variable. Length must match source, and their indices must correspond.

        java.lang.Exception

      • addObservations

        public void addObservations(double[] source,
                   double[] destination)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculator

        Adds a new set of observations to update the PDFs with. It is intended to be called multiple times, and must be called after ChannelCalculatorCommon.startAddObservations(). Call ChannelCalculatorCommon.finaliseAddObservations() once all observations have been supplied.

        Important: this does not append these observations to the previously supplied observations, but treats them independently - i.e. measurements such as the transfer entropy will not join them up to examine k consecutive values in time.

        Note that the arrays source and destination must not be over-written by the user until after ChannelCalculatorCommon.finaliseAddObservations() has been called (they are not copied by this method necessarily, but the method may simply hold a pointer to them).

        Specified by:
        addObservations in interface ChannelCalculator
        Parameters:
        source - series of observations for the source variable.
        destination - series of observations for the destination variable. Length must match source, and their indices must correspond.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

        destination - time series of observations for the destination variable.
        sourceValid - array (with indices the same as source) indicating whether the source at that index is valid.
        destValid - array (with indices the same as destination) indicating whether the destination at that index is valid.

      • addObservations

        public void addObservations(double[] source,
                   double[] destination,
                   int startTime,
                   int numTimeSteps)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculator

        Adds a new set of observations to update the PDFs with, as a subset of the supplied arrays. It is intended to be called multiple times, and must be called after ChannelCalculatorCommon.startAddObservations(). Call ChannelCalculatorCommon.finaliseAddObservations() once all observations have been supplied.

        Important: this does not append these observations to the previously supplied observations, but treats them independently - i.e. measurements such as the transfer entropy will not join them up to examine k consecutive values in time.

        Note that the arrays source and destination must not be over-written by the user until after finaliseAddObservations() has been called (they are not copied by this method necessarily, but the method may simply hold a pointer to them).

        Specified by:
        addObservations in interface ChannelCalculator
        Parameters:
        source - series of observations for the source variable.
        destination - series of observations for the destination variable. Length must match source, and their indices must correspond.
        startTime - first index to take observations on
        numTimeSteps - number of steps from and including startTime to use
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • preFinaliseAddObservations

        protected void preFinaliseAddObservations()
                                   throws java.lang.Exception
        Hook in case this or child implementations need to perform any processing on the observation time series prior to their being processed and supplied to the underlying MI calculator. Primarily this is to allow this or child implementation to automatically determine embedding parameters if desired. Child implementations do not need to override this default empty implementation if no new functionality is required.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeAdditionalBiasToRemove

                                        throws java.lang.Exception

        Returns:
        additional bias correction to remove (will be zero if assumed to be already bias corrected).
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeStartAndEndTimePairs

        public static java.util.Vector<int[]> computeStartAndEndTimePairs(int k_in_use,
                                                  int k_tau_in_use,
                                                  int l_in_use,
                                                  int l_tau_in_use,
                                                  int delay_in_use,
                                                  boolean[] sourceValid,
                                                  boolean[] destValid)
                                                           throws java.lang.Exception
        Compute a vector of start and end pairs of time points, between which we have valid series of both source and destinations. (I.e. all points within the embedding vectors must be valid, even if the invalid points won't be included in any tuples)

        Made public so it can be used if one wants to compute the number of observations prior to setting the observations.

        Parameters:
        k_in_use - k embedding dimension to use for target
        k_tau_in_use - target tau embedding delay to use
        l_in_use - l embedding dimension to use for source
        l_tau_in_use - source tau embedding delay to use
        delay_in_use - source-target delay to use
        sourceValid - a time series (with indices the same as observations) indicating whether the entry in observations at that index is valid for the source;
        destValid - as described for sourceValid
        Returns:
        a vector for start and end time pairs of valid series of observations.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalOfPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
                                            throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculatorCommon

        Computes the local values of the implemented channel measure, for each valid observation in the previously supplied observations (with PDFs computed using all of the previously supplied observation sets).

        If the samples were supplied via a single call such as #setObservations(double[]), then the return value is a single time-series of local channel measure values corresponding to these samples.

        Otherwise where disjoint time-series observations were supplied using several calls such as addObservations(double[]) then the local values for each disjoint observation set will be appended here to create a single "time-series" return array.

        Specified by:
        computeLocalOfPreviousObservations in interface ChannelCalculatorCommon
        Specified by:
        computeLocalOfPreviousObservations in interface TransferEntropyCalculator
        Returns:
        the "time-series" of local TE values. If the samples were supplied via a single call such as #setObservations(double[]), then this time-series will have zero entries until the source and destination embedding vectors are defined.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations

        public double[] computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[] newSourceObservations,
                                             double[] newDestObservations)
                                               throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ChannelCalculator
        Compute the local measure values for each of the supplied samples in newSourceObservations and newDestObservations.

        PDFs are computed using all of the previously supplied observations, but not those in newSourceObservations and newDestObservations (unless they were some of the previously supplied samples).

        Specified by:
        computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations in interface ChannelCalculator
        Parameters:
        newSourceObservations - series of observations for the source variable (indexed by time or observation index)
        newDestObservations - series of observations for the destination variable (indexed by time or observation index) Length must match newSourceObservations, and their indices must correspond.
        Returns:
        the series of local channel measure values.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int numPermutationsToCheck)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
        Generate an empirical (bootstrapped) distribution of what the given measure would look like, under a null hypothesis that the source values of our samples had no relation to the destination value (possibly in the context of a conditional value).

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for MI, conditional MI and TE.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using addObservations methods etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        References:

        • J.T. Lizier, "JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems", 2014.
        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
        Parameters:
        numPermutationsToCheck - number of surrogate samples to bootstrap to generate the distribution.
        Returns:
        the empirical distribution of measure scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int[][] newOrderings)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
        Generate an empirical (bootstrapped) distribution of what the given measure would look like, under a null hypothesis that the source values of our samples had no relation to the destination value (possibly in the context of a conditional value).

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done MI, conditional MI and TE.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using addObservations methods etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        This method (in contrast to EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer.computeSignificance(int)) allows the user to specify how to construct the surrogates, such that repeatable results may be obtained.

        References:

        • J.T. Lizier, "JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems", 2014.
        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
        Parameters:
        newOrderings - a specification of how to shuffle the next values to create the surrogates to generate the distribution with. The first index is the permutation number (i.e. newOrderings.length is the number of surrogate samples we use to bootstrap to generate the distribution here.) Each array newOrderings[i] should be an array of length N (where would be the value returned by a call to getNumObservations() for the given measure) containing a permutation of the values in 0..(N-1).
        Returns:
        the empirical distribution of measure scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - where e.g. the newOrderings don't supply arrays of the correct length matching the number of observations that we have.
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • getNumObservations

        public int getNumObservations()
                       throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous
        Get the number of samples to be used for the PDFs here which have been supplied by calls to "setObservations", "addObservations" etc.

        Note that the number of samples may not be equal to the length of time-series supplied (e.g. for transfer entropy, where we need to accumulate a number of samples for the past history of the destination).

        Specified by:

        java.lang.Exception
